awd_titl_txt: ATD: Collaborative Research: Adaptive and Rapid Spatial-Temporal Threat Detection over Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop innovative machine learning and statistical algorithms for detecting, preventing, and responding to threats over networks. Two concrete applications are monitoring the threat of multi-antibiotic-resistant (MDR) gonorrhea from a network of clinics across the United States and monitoring HIV transmission in clusters of patients. The research has impact in many other practical applications, including biosurveillance, engineering, homeland security, finance, and public health, where large-scale spatial-temporal data streams are collected with the aim of rapid detection and prevention of threats. The research aims to develop crucial scalable algorithms and methods to effectively and efficiently monitor, analyze, and optimize responses in these situations. In addition, the project will integrate research and education by infusing the research findings into the curriculum and by involving Ph.D. students in research.  

This project aims to develop innovative algorithms for rapid threat detection by combining spatial-temporal models, ordinary differential equation (ODE) models with change-point detection, and multi-armed bandit and ensemble methods when monitoring large-scale spatial-temporal data over networks. In particular, efficient scalable algorithms are developed in three interrelated research tasks, including (1) rapid detection of threats by combining a "background + anomaly + noise" decomposition framework with sequential change-point detection; (2) predictive analytics of threats by applying multi-armed bandit algorithms and adaptive sampling in the changing environments to assess increasing risks at the population level; and (3) prescriptive analytics of threats by developing nested ensemble models based on calibrated ODE and data-driven spatial-temporal models so as to better assess the effects of prevention/intervention actions. Results of the project are expected to significantly advance the state of the art in spatial-temporal models, online learning, streaming data analysis, and large-scale inference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed innovative algorithms for rapid threat detection by combining spatial-temporal models, ordinary differential equation (ODE) models with change-point detection, multi-armed bandit and ensemble methods when monitoring large-scale spatial-temporal data.

From the technical aspects, this project develops algorithms under four different practical settings and constraints. In the first line of work, we developed efficient hot-spots detection algorithms when monitoring spatial-temporal data. The key novel idea is to use the tensor decomposition framework that decompose the observed data into smooth background, sparse hot-spots, and random residuals. Then we combine the LASSO estimators of the sparse hot-spots with the well-known CUSUM procedure to monitor the residuals so as to detect and localize hot-spots.

In the second line of work, we developed efficient detection algorithm that incorporate spatial correlation and/or network topology structure. To be more specific, correlation-based dynamic sampling algorithm is developed for online high dimensional process monitoring by using the correlation structure to infer unobserved local streams from partially observations of local neighbors. In addition, in the context of distributed sequential detection problems, an interesting algorithm is the so-called Consensus-Innovation Sequential Probability Ratio Test (CISPRT) that communicates local information with their immediate neighborhood at each time step so that the sensors can work together to make a quick but accurate decision. We presented sharp finite-sample theoretical properties of  the CISPRT algorithm for Gaussian data.

In the third line of work, we developed adaptive sequential change-point detection algorithm that is asymptotically optimal to monitor the spatial-temporal data under the sampling constraint over the spatial domain. Our proposed method is to adopt the sampling policies in the multi-armed bandit problems that construct suitable local detection statistics to indicate how likely a local change occurs and then to actively select/sample those local streams with largest local detection statistics. It turns out that this allows us to maximize the sensitivity and effectiveness for change detection with consideration of resources constraints.

In the fourth line of work, we developed efficient algorithms to quickly make inference decisions for Bernoulli data. A semi-Bayesian formulation for sequential interval estimation of Bernoulli parameter is formulated and the corresponding Bayes procedure and its theoretical properties are derived. Moreover, a simple but useful sequential algorithm is introduced for tandem-width sequential confidence intervals for a Bernoulli proportion.

Overall, the success of this project advances the state of the art in monitoring spatial-temporal data streams over networks and contribute to the science base of statistics, surveillance,  and quality control in engineering. Moreover, graduate students who worked on the project received training in the areas of statistics, data mining, optimization, and biomedical applications. Furthermore, the technical outcomes were published as ten (10) journal papers in top journals and two (2) conference papers in top conferences in the related areas, and also embedded into several graduate course modules.
